t: Proverbs 26
As*pn snow in summer and rain in harvest, So*ld honor is not fitting for a fool.
Like*ln a flitting sparrow, like a flying swallow, So*ld a curse without cause shall not alight.
A*ln whip for the horse, A*ld bridle for the donkey, And*ld a rod for the fool’s back.
Do*ld not answer a fool according to his folly, Lest*ld you also be like him.
Answer*ld a fool according to his folly, Lest*ld he be wise in his own eyes.
He*ld who sends a message by the hand of a fool Cuts*ld off his*i own*i feet and*i drinks violence.
Like*ild the legs of the lame that hang limp Is*ild a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like*ld one who binds a stone in a sling Is*ild he who gives honor to a fool.
Like*ild a thorn that*i goes into the hand of a drunkard Is*ild a proverb in the mouth of fools.
The*ld great God*i who formed everything Gives*ld the fool his*i hire and the transgressor his*i wages.
As*ld a dog returns to his own vomit, So*ild a fool repeats his folly.
Do*ld you see a man wise in his own eyes? There*ild is*i more hope for a fool than for him.
The*ln lazy man*i says, “There*i is*i a lion in the road! A*ld fierce lion is*i in the streets!”
As*ild a door turns on its hinges, So*ld does*i the lazy man*i on his bed.
The*ld lazy man*i buries his hand in the bowl; It*ld wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.
The*ld lazy man*i is*i wiser in his own eyes Than*ld seven men who can answer sensibly.
He*ln who passes by and*i meddles in a quarrel not his own Is*ild like*i one who takes a dog by the ears.
Like*ln a madman who throws firebrands, arrows, and death,
Is*ild the man who*i deceives his neighbor, And*ld says, “I was only joking!”
Where*ln there*i is*i no wood, the fire goes out; And*ld where there*i is*i no talebearer, strife ceases.
As*ild charcoal is*i to burning coals, and wood to fire, So*ld is*i a contentious man to kindle strife.
The*ld words of a talebearer are*i like tasty trifles, And*ld they go down into the inmost body.
Fervent*ln lips with a wicked heart Are*ild like*i earthenware covered with silver dross.
He*ld who hates, disguises it*i with his lips, And*ld lays up deceit within himself;
When*ld he speaks kindly, do not believe him, For*ld there*i are*i seven abominations in his heart;
Though*ild his*i hatred is covered by deceit, His*ld wickedness will be revealed before the assembly.
Whoever*ln digs a pit will fall into it, And*ld he who rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.
A*ln lying tongue hates those*i who*i are*i crushed by it, And*ld a flattering mouth works ruin.
